title: Travels in lands beyond the sea.
author: Linskill, Charles Dorrance.
snippet: Cheltenham — fine farm country; mountains in distance, quite fine, high, green. Worcester — 'Union Hotel,' read the sign, 'patronized by H. R. H. the Duke of Cambridge, etc., quiet, comfortable and moderate; Mrs. Mirgfield, Proprietress;' fine, green country, full of shade trees. Droitwich — farm country.

title: 'Christopher North,'
author: Gordon, Mary Wilson.
snippet: If I do not, I shall leave orders at the post-office to Bend it on to London, where I hope to be in a week from this day. But in case any accident should happen, I. wish one of you to write to me, the sartie day you get this, directed to me at ' Union Hotel^ Charing Cross, London, to lie till called for," telling me that you are all well. I shall be at Portsmouth (necessarily) a day or two before I go to London, but shall not stay in the metropolis more than one day.

title: A Knight Templar abroad; or, Reminiscences of travel beyond the sea
author: Cord, W. Harlan.
snippet: m. on Saturday, July 14th, and our party were met and heartily welcomed by a large deputation of Sir Knights, headed by Eminent Commander Empson, of Palestine Commandery No. 18, of New York, and by them we were conducted to the Grand Union Hotel, adjacent to the depot, where Eminent Commander Empson greeted us most cordially in a neat speech, wishing us Godspeed on our pilgrimage, which was most happily responded to by Eminent Commander Norman T. Gassette, of Apollo, after which, we pledged each other's health in sparkling champagne at the expense of Palestine No. 18. Then, our party partook of a sumptuous breakfast, and the next thing in order was to make our arrangements for the grand parade to the steamer City of Rome.

title: Abroad. Journal of a tour through Great Britain and on the Continent
author: Coghill, James Henry.
snippet: Owing to the stupidity of the servant of the hotel, or the designs of the landlord to keep us at his house a day longer, we missed the train. I was vexed, and determined not to return to the hotel, and so had our baggage transferred to the Union Hotel close by, where we sound the accommodations superior in every respect to those we left, and the charges more moderate.

title: Rambles in Europe in 1839. With sketches of prominent surgeons, physicians, medical schools, hospitals, literary personages, scenery, etc
author: Gibson, William
snippet: up quarters at the Union Hotel, in Royal Square, whose landlord, a very obliging man, was particularly attentive, from having been treated, as he said, with great kindness by Americans whilst a prisoner at Boston the last war. The approach to the island of Jersey, at high water especially, is very inviting; for the steep promontories' the commanding heights, the diversity of hill and dale, the rocky and precipitous shores, the green slopes, the indented inlets and bays, the cultivated fields, the nume- rous hedges and forests of luxuriant trees, that every- where meet the eye, afford strong temptation to the stranger to land and tarry for a few hours at least.

title: 'Christopher North,'
author: Gordon, Mary Wilson.
snippet: " Union Hotel, Charing Cross, July 16, 1832. " Mt dear Mary : — I have received your kind epistle, and am rather pleased to find you all well.

title: A summer's jaunt across the water.
author: Smith, J. Jay
snippet: We arrived at the Union Hotel near ten o'clock, completely chilled with the evening air of the mountains, glad to

title: 'Christopher North,'
author: Gordon, Mary Wilson.
snippet: " Mt dear Mary : — I have received your kind epistle, and am rather pleased to find you all well. I write these few lines in a great hurry, to tell you to wrajy np in a parcel, two silver soup- spootis, tioo tea spoons, and two silver forks, and direct them to me at Union Hotel, Charing Cross, per mail, without delay. See them booked at the Office.

title: 'Christopher North,'
author: Gordon, Mary Wilson.
snippet: " Union Hotel, Charing Cross, Tuesday Afternoon, Septcmhe)- 25tt, 1832.
